cluster_relations.rel_desc: The merger of two black holes generates gravitational waves.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: WaveType: gravitational waves emitted by coalescing black holes

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The LIGO observatory carried out or made the 2015 discovery of gravitational waves.
The 2015 discovery event is the observation of gravitational waves.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Significance: first observation of gravitational waves

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The 2015 gravitational-wave discovery arose from the merger of two black holes.

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: during the black hole merger event observed
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: SourceEvent: merger of two black holes that produced the signal

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject physical process or event brings about or generates the object phenomenon or signal.
args.justification: The relation describes the merger of two black holes generating gravitational waves; this is a process-outcome production relation where the event yields the waves.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject agent (e.g., an observatory or experiment) carried out or executed the object activity or discovery event.
args.justification: The LIGO observatory is the agent that carried out the 2015 discovery of gravitational waves; this is an execution/agency relation between an instrument/organization and an observational event.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject observation or discovery event is an observation of, or provides empirical evidence for, the object phenomenon or entity.
args.justification: The 2015 discovery event is explicitly described as the observation of gravitational waves; modeling this as the observation event observing the waves is clearer and more reusable than the more awkward 'is_observation_of'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject event or outcome arises from or is caused by the object event or process.
args.justification: The 2015 discovery of gravitational waves is said to arise from the merger of two black holes, which is a straightforward causal-origin relation where the discovery event is caused by the merger event.
This relation links a physical process (black hole merger) to the output it generates (gravitational waves), a typical process-to-output pattern.
The relation captures an agent (LIGO observatory) executing a scientific activity or discovery event, fitting an execution/agency class for scientific activities.
The link is between an observation/discovery event and the phenomenon observed (gravitational waves), which is best treated as an observation-to-target class.
This is explicitly a causal relation where one event (black hole merger) gives rise to another (discovery event), fitting a causal origin/outcome class.
Both relations express causal dependencies: a merger producing waves, and a discovery event being caused by a merger; these are best grouped under causal semantics.
The relation connects an agent (LIGO observatory) with an activity it carried out (discovery event), which is an archetypal agency/execution pattern.
An observation event interacting with or registering a physical phenomenon (gravitational waves) is best captured as an observational interaction between entities.
